title: Housing officials: Fort Knox residents now have recycling options - United States Army
summary: Meade County, Kentucky has partnered with Fort Knox to provide recycling services to the installation's housing communities. Residents now have access to recycling bins for #1 and #2 plastics, aluminum, steel, newspaper, white paper, magazines, and small metal pieces. This partnership benefits both parties, as Meade County gains increased volume of materials to recycle and Fort Knox reduces the amount of waste going to landfills.

title: Quadpack: A range of five mono-material recyclable lipsticks - Premium beauty
summary: Quadpack has launched a full range of five monomaterial lipsticks made of recyclable materials, including aluminium, polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PET). The range, named to reflect the elegance of tall, iconic architectural structures, includes Oculus, Menara, Kouros, Reforma, and Emerald. All these lipstick tubes are top-filling and compatible with standard filling lines.

title: Approval sought for new landfill near Glendale - Niagara Now
summary: Walker Industries is planning to develop the next phase of its landfill on top of the Niagara Escarpment in Niagara-on-the-Lake. The new landfill will be located east of the existing landfill and will require an environmental assessment before it can be opened. Walker Industries is committed to protecting the environment and will use a state-of-the-art liner system to ensure that waste in the landfill is contained.

title: In Vietnam, young people embrace green lifestyles - TUOI TRE NEWS
summary: Vietnamese youth are increasingly adopting green lifestyles by developing innovative approaches to goods production and embracing eco-friendly products. Some young innovators in Vietnam are finding clever uses for recycled materials to create new products, while others are promoting sustainable production methods to reduce environmental impact.

title: Dubai's recycling programme treats over 8,000kg of waste every week - Khaleej Times
summary: The Dubai Municipality runs a program to collect recyclable materials from 17 bins across the emirate, diverting over 8000kg of materials from landfills each week. The program has diverted close to 2.5 million tonnes of waste from landfills since its launch in 2018. The recycling centres are designed to be accessible, using solar energy and equipped with sensors to track the quantity of materials collected.
